questions.text: A patient was rushed to the casualty with complaints of severe suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. On examination, there was gross distension of the lower abdomen. A CT was done as shown. All of the following can cause this condition except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario with a CT showing a grossly distended urinary bladder is suggestive of acute urinary obstruction. Cholinergics do not cause urinary obstruction. Anticholinergics and opiates cause urinary retention. 

Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Its clinical features include:

  • Inability to pass urine
  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • A distended, palpable, and tender bladder (shown below)

Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually in BPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they are flexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, can be used to overcome the urethral obstruction.

If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. 

If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators. In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in the distal urethra than the proximal urethra.

Significant hematuria can result in the formation of blood clots, which can further block the urethra and cause retention.

Light microscopy of the renal biopsy specimen showed no abnormalities. Diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane was seen on electron microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with normal findings on light microscopy and diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy are highly suggestive of benign familial hematuria (thin basement membrane disease).

It is a type of hereditary nephritis manifested clinically by familial asymptomatic hematuria.

questions.text: A patient presents with the clinical features of hematuria and proteinuria of 500 mg/dL. Urine microscopy shows a cast, as shown in the image given below. What is your inference from this slide?

choices.text: It is specific to advanced chronic kidney disease.
This structure is composed of albumin mainly.

questions.solution:
The urine microscopy shows orange-red to brown colored casts, which are suggestive of RBC casts. This finding is specific to glomerulonephritis and vasculitis. 

This is a case of glomerular hematuria because the presence of even a single RBC cast suggests a glomerular origin of hematuria.

RBC casts form as RBCs entering the tubule fluid become trapped in the cylindrical mold of Tamm-Horsfall protein. For the diagnosis of glomerular diseases from urine, the 40/5/1 rule is followed:

  • 40% dysmorphic RBCs
  • 5% acanthocytes (a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs)
  • Even a single (1) RBC cast

In advanced chronic kidney disease, broad casts are seen. Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:

Glomerular Non-glomerular

Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size)

Isomorphic RBCs seen (normal shape and size)

RBC casts may be present

RBC casts always absent

MCV  is low (<72 fl)

MCV is normal

Protein leakage is more (>1 g/day)

Protein leakage is less (<1 g/day)

The cause is usually medical.

The cause is usually surgical.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.

The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash. 

Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information

Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to describe the hematuria that most urological malignancies cause?
questions.solution:
Most urological malignancies typically present with gross painless hematuria.

Bladder carcinomas and renal cell carcinomas which make up most of the malignancies in the urogenital system very commonly present with gross painless hematuria. Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved. The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria.

Haematuria refers to the occurrence of blood in the urine, which can be observed visually or confirmed through the use of a urine dipstick or urine microscopy. The prevalence of underlying malignancy in patients with visible haematuria is estimated to be around 14%, whereas in patients with non-visual haematuria, it is approximately 3%. However, it is important to note that the likelihood of finding an underlying malignancy is considerably lower in individuals younger than 45 years old.

Haematuria is categorized into the following classifications:

  • Visible haematuria (VH), previously referred to as "macroscopic" or "gross" haematuria, is characterized by the presence of blood in the urine, resulting in a pink, red, or dark brown discolouration.
  • Non-visible haematuria (NVH), previously referred to as "microscopic" or "dipstick positive," is characterized by the presence of blood in the urine as detected through urinalysis, yet being undetectable by visual observation. This can be further classified into:
  • Symptomatic non-visible haematuria (s-NVH) refers to the presence of haematuria, as confirmed through urinalysis or microscopy, accompanied by accompanying symptoms such as suprapubic pain or renal colic.
  • Asymptomatic non-visible haematuria (a-NVH) refers to the presence of blood in the urine, as confirmed by urinalysis or microscopy, without any accompanying symptoms.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD an is undergoing dialysis. The hematuria seen in this patient can be categorized as?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a child with hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and eye defects with normal renal biopsy is consistent with Alport Syndrome which can be classified under persistent hematuria.

Hematuria can be classified into three types:

  • Macroscopic hematuria
  • Transient hematuria
  • Persistent hematuria

Causes of each type are as listed below:

Macroscopic hematuria Transient hematuria Persistent hematuria
Urinary tract infections strenuous exercise benign familial hematuria
blunt abdominal trauma trauma idiopathic hypercalciuria
nephrolithiasis menstruation IgA nephropathy
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis bladder catheterization Alport’s syndrome
IgA nephropathy fever sickle cell trait and or anaemia 
malignancy digital rectal examination drugs or toxins

Various etiologies can give rise to microscopic hematuria; nevertheless, to be recognized as such, the presence of blood in the urine can only be detected through urine analysis rather than visual observation. After presenting with symptoms of hematuria, this possibility has been eliminated as a potential diagnosis for the patient.

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

questions.text: During a regular physical assessment, a 15-year-old male with no known health problems was found to have asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. The urinalysis performed is normal. Urine microscopy demonstrates the presence of 4 - 5 RBCs per high-power field with the absence of bacteria, white blood cells or pus. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (>3 RBCs per high power field) can be best advised to return after 2 weeks to see if hematuria is persistent. It is important to note that most patients with isolated microscopic hematuria are usually self-limiting.

The occurrence of isolated microscopic hematuria can be observed in up to 1% of school-age children who are healthy and asymptomatic. According to the data, a minority of individuals, namely less than 25%, will experience chronic hematuria when repeat measures are taken. If microscopic hematuria continues to occur, it is recommended to do screening procedures to assess renal function, renal structure, urine calcium excretion, and potential infection. The most common cause of microscopic hematuria in children is hypercalciuria.

According to the recommendations established by the American Urological Association (AUA), microscopic hematuria (MH) is characterized by the presence of three or more red blood cells (RBCs) per high-power field (HPF) as observed during urine microscopy, which should be consistently identified on one or more times. The utilization of urine dipstick testing alone is inadequate for the accurate identification of microscopic hematuria 
Microscopic hematuria (MH) is a prevalent condition, affecting roughly 6.5% of adults. The prevalence of MH varies depending on the specific characteristics of the community under consideration. Approximately 3.5% of patients who have been assessed for asymptomatic MH have been found to have malignancy. Patients with higher degrees of hematuria, male gender, and/or risk factors for malignancy are associated with an increased likelihood of being diagnosed with malignancy. Conversely, the lack of these risk factors is associated with a decreased risk of malignancy diagnosis.

Some differentials that are to be kept in mind as causes of asymptomatic hematuria are as follows :

Neoplasm Infections Congenital or acquired Other
Renal cancer Hemorrhagic cystitis Urinary diverticulum Papillary necrosis
Bladder cancer Pyelo-nephritis Ureteropelvic junction obstruction  Endometriosis
Urethral cancer Schisto-somiasis Fistula Exercise-induced
Prostate cancer Urethritis Polycystic kidney disease Bladder calculi


Other options:

Option A: Cystoscopy is indicated in patients with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria aged 35 years and older( < 35 years in those with risk factors such as benzene exposure or smoking ) according to the AUA guidelines with risk factors of malignancy.

questions.text: A child presents for follow up for IgA nephropathy. Among the given clinical findings, which of the following would indicate a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In patients with IgA nephropathy, persistent hypertension at follow up is indicative of poor prognosis. 

IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease) is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Clinically, children and young adults present with gross or microscopic hematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory (synpharyngitic presentation) or gastrointestinal infection.

The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension and chronic renal failure in severe cases. IgA nephropathy in children is associated with an increased risk of progressive disease developing later in adulthood, prompting the need for careful long term follow up.

Indicators of poor prognosis at presentation or follow-up include persistent hypertension, decreased renal function, and significant, increasing, or prolonged proteinuria. Histologic evidence of diffuse mesangial proliferation, extensive glomerular crescents, glomerulosclerosis, and diffuse tubulointerstitial changes (such as inflammation and fibrosis) are correlated with more severe prognosis.

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added.

Other options : 

Option B: Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic or prognostic value in IgA nephropathy because they are elevated in only 15% of pediatric patients.

Option C: Serum C3 levels in IgA nephropathy are characteristically normal, and rarely low C3 levels are seen in severe cases.

Option D: History of recurrent hematuria is common in IgA nephropathy and is not related to prognostication.

questions.text: A patient presents with the clinical features of hematuria and proteinuria of 600 mg/dL. Which of the following features raises suspicion of a glomerular origin of this patient's hematuria?
questions.solution:
Individuals with glomerular-origin hematuria frequently exhibit dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs), whereas individuals with non-glomerular-origin hematuria typically present with isomorphic RBCs.

This is a case of glomerular hematuria and the presence of even a single RBC cast suggests a glomerular origin of hematuria.

RBC casts form as RBCs entering the tubule fluid become trapped in the cylindrical mold of Tamm-Horsfall protein. For the diagnosis of glomerular diseases from urine, the 40/5/1 rule is followed:

  • 40% dysmorphic RBCs
  • 5% acanthocytes (a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs)
  • Even a single (1) RBC cast

In advanced chronic kidney disease, broad casts are seen. Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:

Glomerular Non-glomerular

Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size)

Isomorphic RBCs seen (normal shape and size)

RBC casts may be present

RBC casts always absent

MCV  is low (<72 fl)

MCV is normal

Protein leakage is more (>1 g/day)

Protein leakage is less (<1 g/day)

The cause is usually medical.

The cause is usually surgical.


Other options:

Option A: Granular or muddy casts are characteristically seen in patients with acute tubular necrosis.

Option C: Fresh blood in urine is seen in patients with lower urinary bleeding, for example, urethral bleeds.

questions.text: During the cystoscopic evaluation of a patient with hematuria, where will you find the Mercier's bar?

choices.text: Between uvula vesicae and ureteric orifice
Between internal and external urethral orifice

questions.solution:
The Mercier's bar (interureteric bar or interureteric ridge) is a curved fold of mucous membrane between the two ureteric orifices inside the bladder.

This fold of mucous membrane is formed by the thickening of the superior border of the trigone muscle. In cystoscopy, the interureteric ridge appears as a pale band and acts as a guide to the ureteric orifices.

The mucosal fold running from the uvula vesicae to the ureteric orifice is called the Bell's bar. This fold forms the lateral borders of the trigone. It contains a band of muscle fibres called the Bell's muscle.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The gross specimen image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis is bladder carcinoma. 

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumor. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumor. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options: 

Option A- Leukoplakia is squamous metaplasia of the bladder characterized by white particles (keratin) in the urine. Diffuse leukoplakia of the bladder is pre-malignant and can lead to squamous cancer of the bladder. It has to be assessed by cystoscopy and localized areas may be resected.

Option C- Prostate carcinoma presents with symptoms only during advanced disease. It causes bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, and renal failure. It is surgically managed by radical prostatectomy, which only involves the removal of the prostate and seminal vesicles and preserving the bladder. Unlike the given gross specimen one or more lobes are predominantly involved in prostatic carcinoma.

Option D- Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium. Cystoscopy would show nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, or sandy patches. Chronic infection can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the pathogenesis behind BPH-related hematuria?

BPH - Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia

choices.text: Reduced blood flow to the transitional zone

questions.solution:
The cause for BPH-related hematuria has been thought to be increased prostatic vascularity resulting from higher microvessel density in hyperplastic prostate tissue. This noted increase in microvessel density has in turn been linked to higher levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

Painless gross hematuria in an elderly man is indicative of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). BPH is the most common cause of gross hematuria in the elderly. So, in this case, the investigation of choice is ultrasonography kidney-ureter-bladder (USG KUB).

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Recurrent gross hematuria
  • Recurrent bladder stones
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with renal functional impairment

Other options

Option A: It has been implicated that anti-androgens have reduced the incidence of hematuria in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia, hence imparting androgens role in increasing angiogenesis.

Option B: There is increased blood flow and not reduced blood flow to the transitional zone of the prostate.

Option D: There is increased VEGF transcription due to increased angiogenesis.

questions.text: The X-ray pelvis of a 44-year-old man with intermittent haematuria for the past 3 years is shown below. This condition predisposes to _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows calcification of the bladder wall which is seen in schistosomiasis. Bladder schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia of the bladder, predisposes individuals to squamous cell carcinoma.

Imaging findings in schistosomiasis are suggestive of the pathologic course. In the acute phase, nodular bladder wall thickening is seen at urography or cross-sectional imaging. The characteristic finding in the chronic phase is a contracted, fibrotic, thick-walled bladder with calcifications. The calcifications are usually curvilinear and these represent the large numbers of calcified eggs in the bladder wall. A mass may be secondary to inflammation or complicating carcinoma, typically SCC.

questions.text: A patient presents with high colored urine. A urine dipstick test done was positive. On further evaluation by centrifugation at 2000rpm for 5 min, the sample was still high colored but became colorless after about 3 hours.  Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myoglobinuria is most likely in this patient.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme which is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or due to porphyrias.

Myoglobinuria is the presence of an excess amount of myoglobin in the urine. It is mostly caused by muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury. 

Causes of myoglobinuria:

  • Physical causes are trauma, crush injury, heatstroke, hypothermia, malignant hyperthermia, extensive burns, seizures, strenuous exercise, and prolonged immobility.
  • Non-physical causes include hypoxic injury, metabolic disturbances, genetic disorders, infections, drugs, and toxins.

The primary goal of treatment in the case of myoglobinuria is to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI), and for that, the initial therapy is mainly focused on rehydration to facilitate the renal clearance of myoglobin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis is typically painless.

Hematuria from within the glomerulus is often associated with brown-, cola-, or tea-colored urine. Urine analysis reveals RBC casts and deformed urinary RBCs (particularly acanthocytes).

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: What is the most common manifestation of Alport's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of Alport syndrome is gross or microscopic hematuria, frequently accompanied by red cell casts.

Proteinuria and oliguria may develop later in the disease, and rarely, nephrotic syndrome develops. The deafness may be subtle requiring sensitive testing.

There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy, the glomerular basement membrane shows: 

  • Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning)
  • Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - basket-weave appearance

questions.text:
Which of the following would be considered significant hematuria?

hpf - high power field
questions.solution:
The criteria for significant hematuria is RBC >100 in a single urinalysis.

Hematuria is considered significant (or persistent) when:

  • RBC >3/hpf on >3 occasions
  • RBC >100 in single urinalysis
  • Gross hematuria

questions.text: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis in children is diagnosed by______

choices.text: Heavy proteinuria, high cholesterol, high ASO titre
Heavy proteinuria, hematuria, low ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, hematuria, high ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, high cholesterol, normal ASO titre

questions.solution:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a classical example of nephritic syndrome characterized by 

  • Hematuria
  • Mild proteinuria,
  • Elevated levels of antistreptolysin O (ASO) and anti-DNAase antibodies (indicative of streptococcal infection) and
  • Reduced levels of serum C3.

Glomerular Syndromes

Nephrotic syndrome

Massive proteinuria, Anasarca, Hyperlipidemia, Lipiduria

Nephritic syndrome

Haematuria, Hypertension, Mild proteinuria

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

Acute nephritis, proteinuria, and acute renal failure

Chronic renal failure

Azotemia and uremia progressing for many years

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of burning micturition, hematuria, and flank pain. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. What are the serotypes of adenovirus implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus serotypes 11 and 21 cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children.

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It is benign and self-limited. It more commonly affects boys than girls. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. Microscopic hematuria and dysuria may persist for several more days, but renal function tests show normal results. 

Adenovirus types 11 and 21 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Urinary tract infections in children are most commonly caused by the following:

  • Escherichia coli (most common)
  • Klebsiella species
  • Proteus species
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus
  • Enterococcus
  • Adenovirus and other viruses (cause cystitis and gross hematuria)

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD because of repeated attacks of dermatitis. On examination, ulceration and scarring can be seen on the sun-exposed areas like his face and limbs. He also has reddish-brown discolouration of teeth. On investigation, urine discoloration is observed as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows reddish discoloration of urine known as a port-wine appearance. The clinical scenario describes photosensitivity and erythrodontia (reddish-brown discoloration of teeth). All these features are suggestive of congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and feces.

The most characteristic presentation is port-wine urine or pink staining of diapers by urine. Reddish-brown teeth are seen under normal light and when illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
